abstracts.cdata!:
The National Land Management and
            Livestock Project in Botswana was applied. Bank-Borrower
            relationships were excellent. They cooperated well at the
            crucial times when the project required restructuring, and
            later when need arose to extend the life of the project. The
            project got off to a slow start, due to its relatively
            complex structure aggravated by a run of dry years, staffing
            delays and the high level of loans in arrears by the
            National Development Bank (NDB) clients, which severely
            reduced the utilization of credit funds made available by
            the project. As soon as it was launched, the project also
            became a target of environmental lobbyists who viewed it as
            environmental unfriendly. A lot of effort had to be put in
            by both the Bank and Government to defray these criticisms.
            The project demonstrated the need for careful analysis of
            all relevant data, including rainfall data, and of
            input/output parameters, in areas such as ranch development
            and land use planning. It further demonstrated the need, for
            smaller and more manageable projects and for the adoption of
            a process approach, with a built-in mechanism for regular
            reviews, to which project implementation can respond quickly
            and flexibly, adjusting project inputs according to need.
            Finally, the project re-enforced the need for thorough
            analysis, at appraisal, of the operations and capacities of
            key institutions which will be involved in project implementation.
